contextId.information: Here the word "countries" represents all of the armies that have gathered to attack. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
God's fingers represent him. AT: "the heavens which you have made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: your heavens, which your fingers have made

contextId.information: The eyes represent him. AT: "he looks for some helpless victim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: his eyes look for some helpless victim

contextId.information: Here "your eyes" refers to that which Yahweh knows to be true. AT: "you know that I am telling the truth!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: let your eyes see what is right!

contextId.information: Here "face" represents Yahweh in all of his being. David is confident he will see Yahweh. AT: "because I act in the right way, I will be with you one day" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I will see your face in righteousness

contextId.information: This refers to enabling a person to run fast. AT: "makes me run very fast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "my hands" refers to the person. AT: "He trains me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "my feet" refers to the person. The writer refers to the safety of God's protection as if he were standing on a place where he will not slip or fall. AT: "I have not slipped" or "I am doing well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
All three of these words refer to the whole person. AT: "a person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the soul ... the heart ... the eyes

contextId.information: Here "heart" stands for the entire person. The abstract noun "desire" can be stated as a verb. AT: "what you desire" or "what you want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "hearts" represent the whole person. AT: "May you live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "my soul" refers to the writer. AT: "brought me up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "my glory" refers to the writer's soul or heart or inner being. This represents the entire person of the writer, who worships God because God has made him glad. AT: "I will sing praise to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: my glory will sing praise to you

contextId.information: Here "my soul" refers to the writer. AT: "my distress"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "my bones" refers to the writer. AT: "I was wasting away" or "I was getting weaker" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "hand" refers to Yahweh. The entire phrase is an idiom that means "you afflicted me." AT: "you made me suffer greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: your hand was heavy upon me

contextId.information: Here "their lives" refers to the people. AT: "to keep them from dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: to deliver their lives from death

contextId.information: Here "tongue" refers to the whole person. AT: "Therefore, do not speak evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Then keep your tongue from evil

contextId.information: Both "swords" and "bows" are weapons used to attack people. The fact that they are "drawn" and "bent" means they are ready to start attacking. AT: "have prepared their weapons in order to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: have drawn out their swords ... have bent their bows

contextId.information: Swords are examples of weapons and "hearts" represent the people. To "pierce the heart" is an idiom that means "to kill." AT: "Their weapons will be turned against them and they will kill themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Their swords will pierce their own hearts

contextId.information: Here "my heart" refers to the writer. It may be helpful to state that the writer desires good health. AT: "My strongest desires" or "that I desire you to heal me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here "heart" represents the whole person. The anxious thoughts of the writer are spoken of as if they were a fire burning inside him. AT: "I became very anxious when I thought about these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My heart became hot ... it burned like a fire

contextId.information: Here "my mouth" refers to the writer. AT: "in me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "mouth" refers to the whole person who speaks. AT: "I will speak wise words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "life" refers to the whole person. AT: "God will redeem me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here the word "soul" refers to the whole person. This phrase means that he considered himself to be happy and successful because of his riches. AT: "He congratulated himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

God speaks of a person speaking evil things as if that person's mouth is a messenger whom the person sends to do evil things. AT: "You are always saying evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: You give your mouth to evil

contextId.information: Here "the mouth" represents the whole person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "but God will silence the liars" or "but God will silence those who lie" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: but the mouth of those who speak lies will be stopped up

contextId.information: This refers to all of the people who live on the earth. AT: "All the people on earth will worship you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: All the earth will worship you

contextId.information: Here "them" refers to the names of the enemies. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Wipe out their names in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Let them be blotted out of

contextId.information: The psalmist speaks of his desire to praise and honor Yahweh with the words he speaks as if his mouth were full of words the way it can be full of food. AT: "My mouth will be filled with words that praise you ... that honor you" or "I will always praise you ... will always honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: My mouth will be filled with your praise ... with your honor

contextId.information: The mouth is synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "I will tell" or "I will speak with my mouth and tell" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "tongue" refers to the whole person. AT: "I will also talk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The right hand represents the Yahweh's power and control. AT: "This is the root that you, Yahweh, planted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: This is the root that your right hand planted

contextId.information: This refers to Yahweh's power and control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Joseph" represents all of the Israelites. AT: "to the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "the burden from his shoulder" represents the forced labor the Israelites had to do as slaves in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: removed the burden from his shoulder

contextId.information: Here "Israel" represents the people of Israel. AT: "Israelites" or "people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]]).
Here "faces" represents the whole person. AT: "Make them very ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "courts" represent the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "gates of Zion" represents the entire city of Jerusalem. AT: "city of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "edge" represents the whole sword. AT: "his sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"control of the wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here the author refers to himself as his "heart." This can be stated in active form. AT: "I am in despair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Here David is referring to himself by his heart. Also, the word "fixed" means to trust completely. AT: "My heart is fixed on you, God" or "I am trusting completely in you, God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "hands" refers to Yahweh, himself. AT: "The works that he does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"His heart is supported." Here the word "heart" refers to the person. Possible meanings are 1) "He is at peace" or 2) "He is confident" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The verbal phrase may be supplied from the previous phrase to make the meaning clear. The feet here represent the person. Stumbling here probably represents being killed by his enemies. AT: "you have rescued me from stumbling" or "you have kept me from being killed by my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Here "mouth" represents the whole person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "body" represents the whole person. AT: "I shake because I fear you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: My body trembles in fear of you

contextId.information: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. AT: "I grow tired because I wait and wait" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: My eyes grow tired as I wait

contextId.information: Here the word "footsteps" represents the writer as he is walking. He speaks of the way he lives, or his conduct, as if he were walking on a path. AT: "Direct me" or "Teach me how to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The psalmist speaks of his whole being as if it were only his heart. AT: "completely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The hand is a synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "Please help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here Jerusalem is referred to by the fortress walls that protects it. The terms "walls" and "fortress" refer to the same thing. AT: "within Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: within the walls that defend you ... within your fortresses

contextId.information: "My soul" represents the psalmist. AT: "I" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "your sons" represents the descendants of David that would become king. AT: "your descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"Inner parts" refers to the interior organs of a person, but here the expression probably stands for the entire body. AT: "You made my entire body (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The eyes are a synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "I am looking to see what you will do" or "I expect you to help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is a request. AT: "bring me out of prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Bring my soul out of prison

contextId.information: Here "princes" represents all human leaders. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
